marklogic.body:
Hey Peter,
In the spirit of discourse, I agree that our lives are filled with healthy forms of bacteria and fungi that enrich our lives, but I have to hold firm on my opinion of xanthan gum, because at the end of the day, that’s all it is, really, a silly little opinion of mine. Opinions are like onions, when we cut into them, they might cause our eyes to run a bit, but once we try them on, or in this case, taste them, we find that we actually like them. I have severe mold allergies and xanthan gum happens to be derived from one that my body doesn’t agree with, so biology led me down a different gluten free path, if you will. Guar gum can’t be had by all, either, especially those that have sever legume allergies, so the debate is divided, to be sure. Xanthan gum is three times as expensive as guar gum, however, so there is that to take into consideration. I hadn’t noticed guar gum not being able to tolerate high Heats as well as xanthan gum, though. Do you mean for frying in a pan? I’ve had great success using guar gum for everything from fried chicken and donuts.
Can’t wait to meet you in Chicago!!! Cheers! Karen
